current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

term.#text:
Día de
		  los Niños: Celebrating Young Americans

cosponsor.#tail:
) submitted the following
			 resolution; which was considered and agreed to

text.#text: That the

term.#text: Día de los Niños: Celebrating Young Americans

text.#text:
designates April
			 30, 2013, as

calls on the
			 people of the United States to join with all children, families, organizations,
			 communities, churches, cities, and States across the United States to observe
			 the day with appropriate ceremonies, including activities that—

are positive and
			 uplifting, and help children express their hopes and dreams;

include all
			 members of a family, especially extended and elderly family members, so as to
			 promote greater communication among the generations within a family, which will
			 enable children to appreciate and benefit from the experiences and wisdom of
			 their elderly family members;

provide
			 opportunities for families within a community to get acquainted; and

provide children
			 with the support they need to develop skills and confidence and find the inner
			 strength, will, and fire of the human spirit to make their dreams come
			 true.

Whereas many countries throughout the world, and
			 especially within the Western hemisphere, celebrate

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, approximately 17,400,000 of the nearly 52,000,000
			 individuals of Hispanic descent living in the United States are children under
			 the age of 18, representing more than 33 percent of the total Hispanic
			 population residing in the United States;

text.#text:
Whereas, according to the 2011 American Community Survey
			 by the

Whereas Hispanics, the youngest and fastest growing ethnic
			 community in the United States, continue the tradition of honoring their
			 children on Día de los Niños, and wish to share this custom with the rest of
			 the United States;

Whereas the importance of literacy and education is most
			 often communicated to children through their family members;

Whereas the designation of a day of special recognition
			 for the children of the United States will provide an opportunity for children
			 to reflect on their future, articulate their aspirations, and find comfort and
			 security in the support of their family members and communities;

term.#tail:
, a day to bring together Hispanics and other communities in
			 the United States to celebrate and uplift children; and
term.#text:
Día de los Niños: Celebrating Young
			 Americans

text.#text:
Whereas the National Latino Children's Institute, serving
			 as a voice for children, has worked with cities throughout the United States to
			 declare April 30, 2013, to be

Whereas the children of a country are the responsibility
			 of all of the people of that country, and people should be encouraged to
			 celebrate the gifts of children to society: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 SRES 125 ATS: Designating April 30, 2013, as Día de los Niños: Celebrating Young Americans.
